name: Get Vertex from Quadratic Equation in Different Forms
description:
Given an quadratic equation `eq`, return the vertex as a tuple `(x,y)` which represents the coordinate where an extremum appears

`eq` is a quadratic equation (as a string) that is in one of these forms:
- Factored Form - in the form of `(x + a)(x + b)`
- Standard Form - in the form of `ax2 + bx + c` where x2 represents x squared
- Vertex Form - in the form of `a(x - h)2 + k`

This is relatively straightforward to do. The vertex formula `-(b/2a) ` can be very useful in this problem (Especially for calculating the vertex from a equation in Standard Form)

# Notes
- `eq` will always be in one of the forms stated above and will not contain any extra spaces
- Do not round any numbers
- Make sure the returned results are floats

# Examples
```python
# Factored Form
get_vertex("(x + 6)(x + 7)") # returns (-6.5, -0.25)
get_vertex("(x - 4)(x - 3)") # returns (3.5, -0.25)
# Standard Form
get_vertex("x2 - 6x - 3") # returns (3.0, -12.0)
get_vertex("x2 + 6x + 3") # returns (-3.0, -6.0)
# Vertex Form
get_vertex("3(x - 15)2 + 2") # returns (15.0, 2.0)
get_vertex("7(x - 12)2 + 16") # returns (12.0, 16.0)
```
